t: Proverbs 6
Warnings Against Folly
My*pn son, if you have put up security for your neighbor, if*ld you have shaken hands in pledge for a stranger,
you*ln have been trapped by what you said, ensnared*ld by the words of your mouth.
So*ln do this, my son, to free yourself, since*ld you have fallen into your neighbor’s hands: Go—to*ln the point of exhaustion— and*ld give your neighbor no rest!
Allow*ln no sleep to your eyes, no*ld slumber to your eyelids.
Free*ln yourself, like a gazelle from the hand of the hunter, like*ld a bird from the snare of the fowler.
Go*pn to the ant, you sluggard; consider*ld its ways and be wise!
It*ln has no commander, no*ld overseer or ruler,
yet*ln it stores its provisions in summer and*ld gathers its food at harvest.
How*pn long will you lie there, you sluggard? When*ld will you get up from your sleep?
A*ln little sleep, a little slumber, a*ld little folding of the hands to rest—
and*ln poverty will come on you like a thief and*ld scarcity like an armed man.
A*pn troublemaker and a villain, who*ld goes about with a corrupt mouth,
who*ld winks maliciously with his eye, signals*ld with his feet and*ld motions with his fingers,
who*ld plots evil with deceit in his heart— he*ld always stirs up conflict.
Therefore*ln disaster will overtake him in an instant; he*ld will suddenly be destroyed—without remedy.
There*pn are six things the Lord*s hates, seven*ld that are detestable to him:
haughty*ld eyes, a*ld lying tongue, hands*ld that shed innocent blood,
a*ld heart that devises wicked schemes, feet*ld that are quick to rush into evil,
a*ld false witness who pours out lies and*ld a person who stirs up conflict in the community.
Warning Against Adultery
My*pn son, keep your father’s command and*ld do not forsake your mother’s teaching.
Bind*ln them always on your heart; fasten*ld them around your neck.
When*ln you walk, they will guide you; when*ld you sleep, they will watch over you; when*ld you awake, they will speak to you.
For*ln this command is a lamp, this*ld teaching is a light, and*ln correction and instruction are*ld the way to life,
keeping*ln you from your neighbor’s wife, from*ld the smooth talk of a wayward woman.
Do*pn not lust in your heart after her beauty or*ld let her captivate you with her eyes.
For*pn a prostitute can be had for a loaf of bread, but*ld another man’s wife preys on your very life.
Can*ln a man scoop fire into his lap without*ld his clothes being burned?
Can*ln a man walk on hot coals without*ld his feet being scorched?
So*ln is he who sleeps with another man’s wife; no*ld one who touches her will go unpunished.
People*pn do not despise a thief if he steals to*ld satisfy his hunger when he is starving.
Yet*ln if he is caught, he must pay sevenfold, though*ld it costs him all the wealth of his house.
But*ln a man who commits adultery has no sense; whoever*ld does so destroys himself.
Blows*ln and disgrace are his lot, and*ld his shame will never be wiped away.
For*pn jealousy arouses a husband’s fury, and*ld he will show no mercy when he takes revenge.
He*ln will not accept any compensation; he*ld will refuse a bribe, however great it is.
